conditional_clues.adrian|first patient|vale|first case: Her expression darkens slightly. Adrian was a rice farmer, strong man, father of three young children. He came in October 16 with high fever, muscle pain so bad he could barely walk. I suspected leptospirosis immediately—the conjunctival suffusion, the calf tenderness, the timing after the typhoon. I started IV fluids, antibiotics. But by October 23, his kidneys were failing. Creatinine was 4.8 mg/dL. We tried to transfer him to Lunara for dialysis, but he was too unstable to move. Pulmonary hemorrhage started October 25. He died October 26 at 3:47 AM. His wife—Mr. Anton's daughter-in-law—was holding his hand. Three children now without a father. That's when I knew we couldn't wait anymore for bureaucracy.
conditional_clues.barefoot|boots|protective equipment|why: You have to understand—these are subsistence farmers, daily wage laborers, fishermen. They own maybe one pair of rubber boots, already old and cracked. During the flood, many boots were swept away or damaged. So when the water receded and they started cleaning up, they had no choice. Work barefoot in contaminated mud, or lose your livelihood. Wounds from debris, cuts from broken glass, blisters from wet feet—all entryints for Leptospira. I asked every patient: 'Did you have wounds when you were in the floodwater?' Every single one said yes. Open wounds, contaminated water. Perfect transmission.
conditional_clues.dr mendoza|rhu|dismissed|ignored: Visible frustration. October 16, I called Dr. Mendoza. I said: 'We're seeing a pattern—fever, myalgia, conjunctival suffusion, all adult males from Northbend, all did flood cleanup. This is leptospirosis.' You know what he said? 'Dr. Reyes, let's not jump to conclusions. Many things can cause fever after a typhoon. Send samples for confirmation.' I sent samples October 16! Results came backsitive October 18! Two days! But by then, more people were getting sick. If we'd started public health warnings October 16—'Don't work barefoot in floodwater, cover your wounds, wear protection'—maybe Adrian would still be alive. Maybe Pedro and Ernesto too. But no, right? Young female doctor, probably overreacting. Pause. I'm not bitter. I'm just... I'm tired of people dying because warnings come too late.
conditional_clues.northbend|why northbend|geographic patte: Northbend is low-lying, right along the Kantara River tributary. During Typhoon Halcyon, October 8-10, the whole ward flooded—chest-deep water in some areas. Rice paddies completely submerged. Houses flooded. And rats—after floods, rats are displaced, stressed, shedding more Leptospira in urine. Floodwater becomes a cesspool of rat urine mixed with mud, sewage, dead animals. Northbend was hit hardest by flooding, so highest contamination, highest exposure during cleanup. That's why 28 of 34 cases are from Northbend. The other six cases? Four from East Terrace (also flooded but less severely), two from Central Ward (minimal flooding). It's a perfect dose-response: more flooding = more exposure = more cases.

conditional_clues.pigs|swine|livestock illness|animal case: Let me show you my records. Starting October 9, farmers from Northbend began bringing sick pigs or calling me for farm visits. Clinical signs: high fever, jaundice—you could see it in the whites of their eyes and their skin, yellow. Pregnant sows were aborting—stillborn piglets, some mummified, some born weak and dying within hours. Red-tinged urine in some pigs, indicating hemoglobinuria—blood in urine. Classic signs of leptospirosis in swine. I've been practicing 25 years—I know lepto when I see it. I took blood samples from six pigs, sent them to the veterinary lab in Aruvia City. Four came backsitive for Leptospira antibodies, serovar Pomona and Icterohaemorrhagiae. Those are the same serovars that infect humans.
conditional_clues.amplifying hosts|chronic shedding|transm: Here's how it works. Rats are the primary reservoir—they carry Leptospira in their kidneys, shed bacteria in urine, often without getting sick themselves. Pigs get infected by contact with rat urine—eating contaminated feed, drinking contaminated water. Once infected, pigs can shed large amounts of Leptospira in their urine for months, even after they recover clinically. So pigs become amplifying hosts—they take the bacteria from rats and shed massive quantities, contaminating soil, water, everywhere. Humans then contact contaminated pig urine through farm work, floodwater, cleaning pig pens. It's a transmission chain: rats → pigs → environment → humans. If you want to break that chain, you have to think about animal health, not just human health.

conditional_clues.flood|typhoon|october 8|damage|what happ: Sits back, remembering. October 8, afternoon, rain started. Heavy, constant. By evening, water rising fast. Kantara River tributary overflowed. By midnight, chest-deep water in low-lying areas—Riverside Hamlet, near the old irrigation canal. October 9, morning, water still rising. Families evacuating—some to ward hall, some to higher ground, some to my house, some to the chapel with Pastor Elijah. We had maybe 150 people evacuated at peak. Water didn't start going down until October 10 afternoon. By October 11, you could walk around, but mud everywhere, debris everywhere. Rice fields—total loss. Houses flooded, belongings ruined. Dead animals—rats, chickens, pigs—floating in the water, stuck in mud. It was... it was terrible.
conditional_clues.cleanup|who did cleanup|work|debris: October 10, 11, 12—as soon as water receded enough, the men started cleanup. They had to, because life doesn't stop. Clearing roads so vehicles can pass. Clearing drainage canals so water can flow. Removing debris from houses, yards. Saving what rice could be saved from the fields. Heavy work, exhausting work. They worked barefoot or in damaged boots—because who has extra boots? They had cuts, scrapes, blisters from wet feet. They were in mud, dirty water, all day long. Nobody said, 'Be careful, you might get sick.' Nobody said, 'Cover your wounds.' They just worked. Adrian worked. Tomas worked. The Carver brothers worked. People tried to kill them, burn the carcasses, but there were so many. And the smell—dead animals rotting in the heat. I told the Municipal DRRM Office, 'Send usison, send us traps,' but you know government, slow to respond. By the time they sent anything, rats had already spread everywhere.

Some got sick after—farmers said pigs had fever, yellow eyes, some sows lost their babies. Dr. Villareal—the vet—came to check, but I don't know what he found. Point is: pigs and people live very close here. Pig urine, pig waste—if that gets into floodwater, and people wade through it... you see the problem?

Hospital costs money. Pastor speaks our language, understands our fears. Hospital... sometimes doctors are rude toor people, sometimes they turn people away if they can't pay. So families try Pastor first. If prayer doesn't work, then hospital. Problem is: by the time they go to hospital, sometimes too late. I'm not saying Pastor is bad—he helps in his way. conditional_clues.wounds|cuts|injuries|skin damage: I documented wound types, very carefully. Most common: blisters—from wet feet, friction from damaged boots. conditional_clues.adrian|your son|what happened to him: Long pause, eyes distant. Adrian was my eldest. Strong, good farmer, good father to his three children. October 10, flood just went down, he organized the young men—'We have to clean up, we have to save what we can.' He worked so hard, child. Barefoot in the mud because his boots... the flood took them. His hands, his feet, covered in cuts—from bamboo, from metal roofing blown into the canal, from everything. October 13, late evening, he came home burning with fever. He said, 'Elder (Father), my legs hurt so much I can't stand.' His eyes were red, like blood. We took him to Pastor Elijah first—we always do. Pastor prayed, gave him tea. But October 16, no better, worse, we took him to hospital. They tried... they tried to save him. But his kidneys failed. Blood came from his lungs. October 26, early morning, he died. My son. Gone. Tears. Why? Why did this water take my son?
conditional_clues.rats|rodents|animals behaving strange: Becomes more animated. Child, I've lived here 40 years. I know the land, the animals, the seasons. Three days before people got sick—October 9, maybe October 10—the rats were acting wrong. Usually rats come out at night, hide during day. But these days, rats running everywhere in daylight. Confused, like drunk. Many dead rats appearing—in the canal, in the fields, in the debris. Too many. And the live rats—they were aggressive, not afraid of people. I told my wife, 'Something is wrong. The rats know something.' Then after the flood completely went down, dead rats everywhere. Dozens. Maybe hundreds if you count the whole hamlet. We tried to burn them, bury them, but too many. I think... I think the rats brought the sickness. They died, their... their waste, their urine, went into the floodwater. That's what made my son sick.
conditional_clues.cleanup|what was he doing|work|barefoot: October 10, water just low enough to walk. Adrian and other young men started immediately. Clearing the drainage canal—it was blocked with debris, trash, dead animals, mud. If we don't clear it, next rain floods again. Clearing the road so vehicles can pass. Helping neighbors remove mud from houses. Salvaging rice from the paddies—some could still be saved if dried quickly. Heavy work. They worked 8, 10 hours a day, October 10, 11, 12. Barefoot, because who has extra boots? Some men wrapped plastic bags on their feet, but plastic tears. Adrian's hands—rope cuts from pulling debris, bamboo splinters, rust from old metal. His feet—blisters from walking in mud all day, cuts from stepping on hidden sharp things. I told him, 'Child, be careful, wash your wounds.' But there was so much to do. He didn't stop to rest.
conditional_clues.floodwater|smell|contamination|water qua: The water... it was not clean water, child. Normal flood, it's muddy, brown, but this—this smelled rotten. Like sewage broke open. Like death. You could see garbage floating, dead animals, oil from damaged vehicles. The smell made you sick to your stomach. And where itoled—in the low areas, near the old canal—it stayed for days. Dark water, thick, oily. My water buffalo—smart animal—she wouldn't drink it. She smelled theoled water and walked away, went to find clean water from the higher trough. I thought, 'If the water buffalo knows it's bad, why are we walking in it?' But what choice? Our homes were flooded. We had to clean up or lose everything.
conditional_clues.pastor elijah|faith healer|why not hospi: Pastor Elijah is good man. He helps us. When someone gets sick, we go to him first because—child, you must understand—hospital costs money. We areor. Sometimes hospital turns people away if they can't pay. Pastor prays for free, gives herbs for free. We trust him. Adrian had fever, body pain—we thought, 'Maybe flu, maybe dengue, Pastor can pray for this.' So October 14, 15, we took Adrian to Pastor. He prayed, gave herbal tea for fever. But October 16, morning, Adrian could not walk, fever still very high, jaundice starting—yellow eyes. I said, 'We must go to hospital now.' I borrowed motorcycle, took him myself. Maybe we should have gone October 13, first day of fever. But we didn't know. We thought prayer would work. Now Adrian is gone. Pause. Was it wrong to go to Pastor first? I don't know. I just wanted to save my son.
conditional_clues.flooding|how deep|how long|october 8-10: October 8, afternoon, heavy rain started. By nighttime, water rising fast in Riverside Hamlet. We live in low area, near the old canal. Water came into the house—first ankle, then knee, then waist-high. We moved to higher shelf, waited. October 9, morning, water still rising. Chest-deep outside. We couldn't evacuate—too dangerous to wade that deep. We waited on the roof. Water stayed very high until October 10 afternoon. Then slowly receding. By October 11, you could walk, but mud everywhere,ols of water in low spots. Some areas—near the canal, the rice paddies—water stayed until October 13, 14. That's where Adrian worked. Where the water stayed longest. That's where most people got sick, child. The water that wouldn't leave—that's what brought death.
conditional_clues.prevention|could this happen again|what: Softly. I think... if people knew the floodwater was dangerous, if someone warned us—'Don't work barefoot, cover your wounds, the water is infected'—maybe Adrian would still be alive. We didn't know. We just thought, 'Muddy water, we've seen it before.' But this water was different. It had... it had sickness in it. The rats died first. Then my son. If I could go back, I would tell Adrian: 'Don't work barefoot. Don't touch that water. Your life is worth more than saving some rice.' But we didn't know. Voice breaking. We didn't know.

luz_fernandez.location: Her home in Ward Northbend (recovering, but able to give interview)

She is articulate, detail-oriented, and—unlike many in her community—comfortable with medical terminology and bureaucratic systems, making her an invaluable bridge between the clinical world and the lived community experience. Her survival while three men died weighs on her, but she channels that survivor's guilt into fierce advocacy: someone needs to document what happened, and if the government won't listen to farmers, maybe they'll listen to an educated woman who can speak their language.
luz_fernandez.speech_patterns: Fluent English with occasional regional lingua code-switching, clear and organized speech, uses medical terms accurately (former health worker). Uses 'I believe' and 'in my observation' to frame opinions carefully. Not afraid to criticize authoritieslitely. conditional_clues.symptoms|what it felt like|clinical cour: Sits forward, speaking precisely. October 14, late evening, sudden onset high fever—I took my temperature, 39.8°C. Severe headache, especially behind my eyes. Muscle pain—you know yung feeling na parang pinukpok ka ng martilyo? (Do you know the feeling like you've been hammered?) Especially calves, lower back, thighs. I couldn't walk without help. My eyes became very red—conjunctival suffusion, I learned that term later. October 15, 16, I took paracetamol, tried to rest, thought it was dengue maybe. But no rash, no bleeding. October 17, I noticed jaundice—yellow in my eyes, my skin. Dark urine, like tea. That scared me. My husband said, 'We're going to hospital now.' At hospital, Dr. Reyes suspected leptospirosis immediately. Blood tests showed kidney damage—creatinine 3.2, normal is under 1.2. They started IV antibiotics, lots of fluids. For 3 days I was very sick, fever wouldn't break. But by day 5, I started improving. Discharged October 25. I was lucky. Adrian wasn't.
conditional_clues.cleanup|exposure|what were you doing|bar: October 10, 11, 12—the three days after flood receded enough to move around. My husband and I were cleaning our house—removing mud, saving furniture, washing everything. We also helped neighbors, especially elderly families who couldn't do heavy work. I was barefoot most of the time—my rubber boots had holes, water came in, made blisters, so I took them off. I had cuts on my feet from stepping on debris I couldn't see in the mud—bamboo pieces, broken roof tiles, who knows what. My hands—cuts from moving wet wood, scraping rust from metal. I was in contaminated water up to my waist sometimes, for 4-5 hours each day. I didn't think about infection risk. I just thought, 'We have to clean up, we have to save what we can.' Now I know—every cut was an entryint for Leptospira. Massive exposure.
